_link.title: I can describe the composition and properties of beta radiation

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus particles are high-speed electrons emitted from the nucleus during radioactive decay.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus particles are high-speed electrons.

options: A positron (antimatter equivalent of an electron)

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-plus particles are positrons—the antimatter equivalent of electrons with positive charge.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-plus particles are positrons (antielectrons).

toLevel2.stem: What is the electrical charge of a beta-minus particle?

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus particles (electrons) have a charge of -1.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus particles are electrons with a -1 charge.

toLevel2.stem: At what fraction of the speed of light can beta particles travel?
options: Up to 90% the speed of light
Less than 1% the speed of light

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta particles can travel at speeds up to 90% of the speed of light.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta particles can travel at up to 90% the speed of light.

toLevel2.stem: What material and thickness can stop beta radiation?

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta particles can be stopped by a few millimetres (about 2 mm) of aluminium.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta radiation is stopped by a few millimetres of aluminium.

toLevel2.stem: Beta-minus particles are [[1]], while beta-plus particles are [[2]].

feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Beta-minus = electrons; beta-plus = positrons.

toLevel2.stem: Beta radiation has [[1]] ionising ability and [[2]] penetrating power compared to alpha and gamma radiation.

segments.text: penetrating power compared to alpha and gamma radiation.

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! Beta has medium ionising ability and medium penetrating power—between alpha and gamma.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Beta has medium values for both ionising ability and penetrating power.

toLevel2.stem: Beta particles can penetrate up to [[1]] metre of air and can be stopped by about [[2]] mm of aluminium.

metre of air and can be stopped by about

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! Beta travels up to 1 m in air and is stopped by about 2 mm of aluminium.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Beta penetrates up to 1 m of air; stopped by 2 mm aluminium.

toLevel2.stem: Beta-minus and beta-plus particles have the same charge.

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus (electrons) have -1 charge; beta-plus (positrons) have +1 charge.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. They have opposite charges: β⁻ = -1, β⁺ = +1.

toLevel2.stem: Beta radiation can penetrate human skin.

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta particles have enough penetrating power to pass through skin, unlike alpha particles.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta radiation can penetrate skin, making it more hazardous externally than alpha radiation.

toLevel3.stem: Why do beta particles have greater penetrating power than alpha particles?
options: Beta particles have smaller mass and lower charge, so they interact less frequently with atoms
Beta particles travel slower than alpha particles
Beta particles have a +2 charge that repels atoms
Beta particles are absorbed more easily by materials

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's smaller mass and ±1 charge (versus alpha's large mass and +2) mean fewer interactions per unit distance, allowing deeper penetration.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta's smaller mass and lower charge cause fewer ionising interactions, enabling greater penetration.

toLevel3.stem: Why do beta particles have lower ionising ability than alpha particles?
options: Beta particles have much smaller mass and charge, causing weaker interactions with orbital electrons
Beta particles travel too slowly to ionise atoms
Beta particles are larger than alpha particles

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's small mass (~1/7000 of alpha) and single charge (versus +2) result in weaker electromagnetic interactions and less ionisation per unit distance.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta's smaller mass and single charge (compared to alpha's +2) create weaker interactions with atomic electrons.

toLevel3.stem: What nuclear process produces beta-minus particles?
options: A neutron in the nucleus converts to a proton, emitting an electron
A proton leaves the nucleus as an electron
An alpha particle breaks apart into electrons

feedback.correct: Correct! In beta-minus decay, a neutron transforms into a proton while emitting an electron and an antineutrino.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay involves neutron → proton + electron + antineutrino.

toLevel3.stem: What happens when a beta-plus particle (positron) meets an electron?
options: They annihilate each other, producing gamma rays
They combine to form a neutron
Nothing happens; they pass through each other

feedback.correct: Correct! When matter (electron) meets antimatter (positron), they annihilate, converting their mass to energy as gamma ray photons.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Positron-electron annihilation produces gamma rays (typically two 511 keV photons).

toLevel3.stem: How does the speed of beta particles contribute to their penetrating power?
options: High speeds (up to 90% of light speed) give beta particles momentum to penetrate further before stopping
High speeds make beta particles interact more with atoms
Speed has no effect on penetrating power

feedback.correct: Correct! High kinetic energy from their speed allows beta particles to travel further before losing all energy through ionisation.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. High speeds give beta particles significant kinetic energy, allowing them to penetrate further.

toLevel3.stem: Why is aluminium commonly used as shielding for beta radiation rather than paper or lead?
options: Aluminium's density is appropriate—thick enough to stop beta but lighter and cheaper than lead
Paper is more effective than aluminium for stopping beta
Aluminium converts beta particles into gamma rays

feedback.correct: Correct! Aluminium provides adequate stopping power for beta (a few mm is sufficient) while being lighter, cheaper, and more practical than lead.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Aluminium is an efficient, practical choice—a few millimetres stops beta without the weight and cost of lead.

toLevel3.stem: Beta particles ionise [[1]] atoms per unit distance than alpha particles because of their smaller [[2]] and charge.

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! Smaller mass and charge means fewer ionising interactions per unit distance.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Beta's smaller mass and charge result in fewer ionisations per distance.

toLevel3.stem: Beta-minus decay occurs when a [[1]] converts to a [[2]], emitting an electron.

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! In β⁻ decay: neutron → proton + electron + antineutrino.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Beta-minus decay: neutron transforms into proton + electron.

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! Positron-electron annihilation converts mass to energy as gamma rays.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Annihilation occurs, producing gamma rays.

toLevel3.stem: Beta particles have medium ionising ability because they have medium mass and charge compared to alpha particles and gamma rays.

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's intermediate mass (between massive alpha and massless gamma) and single charge give medium ionising ability.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. This is true—beta's mass and charge are intermediate, resulting in medium ionising ability.

toLevel4.stem: A factory uses a beta source to measure paper thickness. If the paper becomes thicker, what happens to the beta radiation reaching the detector?
options: Less beta radiation reaches the detector because more is absorbed
More beta radiation reaches the detector
The same amount reaches the detector
Beta radiation cannot be used for this purpose

feedback.correct: Correct! Thicker paper absorbs more beta particles, so fewer reach the detector. This change signals the thickness variation.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Thicker material absorbs more beta radiation, reducing the count at the detector.

toLevel4.stem: A radiation safety officer needs to protect workers from a beta-emitting source. What shielding should they recommend?
options: A few millimetres of aluminium sheeting

feedback.correct: Correct! A few millimetres of aluminium effectively stops beta radiation, providing adequate protection.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta requires more than paper (which only stops alpha) but less than gamma shielding—aluminium sheeting works.

toLevel4.stem: In PET scans, fluorine-18 emits positrons. What radiation is actually detected by the scanner?
options: Gamma rays produced when positrons annihilate with electrons in the patient's body
Alpha particles produced by the fluorine

feedback.correct: Correct! Positrons travel only a short distance before annihilating with electrons, producing detectable gamma rays.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. PET detects the gamma rays from positron-electron annihilation, not the positrons themselves.

toLevel4.stem: A beta source is placed 50 cm from a detector and gives a reading of 1000 counts/second. If moved to 2 metres away, predict the approximate reading.
options: The reading will be much lower due to increased air absorption and inverse square law effects
The reading will stay exactly the same
Beta cannot be detected at 2 metres

feedback.correct: Correct! At 2 metres, both air absorption and the inverse square law reduce the detected intensity significantly.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Greater distance means more air absorption and lower intensity following the inverse square law.

toLevel4.stem: A patient receives a beta-emitting radiopharmaceutical for treatment. Where in the body would the radiation have its greatest effect?
options: In tissues immediately surrounding the radiopharmaceutical's location
In the brain regardless of where the drug accumulates

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's medium penetrating power means the radiation primarily affects tissues within a few millimetres of where the isotope accumulates.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta radiation affects nearby tissue (mm range), making it suitable for targeted local treatment.

toLevel4.stem: A Geiger counter designed to detect beta radiation has a thin window. Why is a thin window necessary?
options: Beta particles cannot penetrate thick materials, so a thin window allows them to enter the detector
Thin windows amplify the beta signal
Thick windows would create more beta particles
Beta detectors don't actually need windows

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's limited penetrating power requires a thin window (often mica) to allow particles to enter the detection chamber.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta particles need a thin window to enter the detector; thick material would absorb them.

toLevel4.stem: In radiotherapy, beta-emitting strontium-90 is used for treating eye conditions. Why is beta radiation suitable for this application?
options: Beta penetrates a few millimetres, treating the eye surface without damaging deeper structures
Beta radiation can penetrate the entire eye to treat deep tumours
Beta is the only radiation that affects eye tissue
Beta radiation makes the eye glow for imaging

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's medium penetration treats surface/shallow eye conditions effectively without reaching the lens or retina.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta's limited penetration (mm scale) makes it ideal for treating superficial eye conditions.

feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Thicker materials absorb more beta, decreasing detector readings.

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! Thin windows are needed because beta's limited penetration would be blocked by thick materials.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Thin windows allow beta particles (limited penetration) to enter the detector.

toLevel4.stem: PET scanners detect the [[1]] rays produced when positrons from the tracer [[2]] with electrons in the patient.

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! PET detects gamma rays from positron-electron annihilation events.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Positrons annihilate with electrons, producing gamma rays that PET detects.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why beta particles show a continuous energy spectrum while alpha particles from the same isotope all have the same energy.
options: In beta decay, energy is shared between the beta particle and a neutrino, giving variable kinetic energies
Beta particles lose random amounts of energy immediately after emission
Alpha decay also produces a continuous spectrum
Beta particles gain energy from surrounding atoms

feedback.correct: Correct! The neutrino carries away variable energy, leaving the beta particle with anything from zero to maximum kinetic energy.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta decay produces three particles (daughter, beta, neutrino), with energy shared variably between beta and neutrino.

toLevel5.stem: Compare the biological damage from beta radiation versus gamma radiation when both are delivering the same absorbed dose to tissue. Analyze the difference.
options: Beta causes slightly more damage because its charge causes more ionisation along its path compared to gamma's scattered interactions
Both cause identical damage at the same absorbed dose
Gamma causes much more damage due to its higher penetration

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's radiation weighting factor is 1 (same as gamma for external exposure), but the ionisation density along beta tracks is slightly higher than gamma's scattered interactions.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta and gamma have similar weighting factors (~1), but beta's charged particle nature creates slightly denser ionisation tracks.

toLevel5.stem: A hospital is choosing between a beta-emitting and gamma-emitting isotope for treating a superficial skin cancer. Evaluate which would be more appropriate.
options: Beta-emitting isotope, because its limited penetration treats the surface without damaging deeper tissue
Gamma-emitting isotope, because it provides uniform dose throughout

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's mm-scale penetration delivers dose to superficial tissue while sparing underlying structures, ideal for surface lesions.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. For superficial cancers, beta's limited penetration is advantageous—treating the surface while protecting deeper tissue.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why PET imaging uses positron emitters rather than beta-minus emitters.
options: Positrons annihilate with electrons producing two detectable gamma rays, enabling precise localization; beta-minus particles don't produce such signals
Beta-minus particles cannot be produced by medical isotopes
Positrons travel further in tissue than beta-minus

feedback.correct: Correct! Positron annihilation produces two 511 keV gamma rays traveling in opposite directions, enabling coincidence detection and precise spatial localization.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. PET relies on detecting the paired gamma rays from positron-electron annihilation for image reconstruction.

toLevel5.stem: A thickness gauge manufacturer must choose between alpha, beta, and gamma sources for measuring plastic film thickness (0.1-1 mm). Evaluate the best choice.
options: Beta source: its medium penetration is appropriate for millimetre-scale measurements—alpha would be fully stopped, gamma would pass through with minimal absorption change
Alpha source: it provides the highest sensitivity
All three sources would work equally well

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's penetration matches the measurement range. Alpha can't penetrate even thin plastic; gamma wouldn't show measurable absorption changes at these thicknesses.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta's penetration matches mm-scale films; alpha would be stopped completely; gamma wouldn't show sufficient absorption variation.

toLevel5.stem: The continuous energy spectrum of beta particles creates challenges for radiation detection. Analyze how this affects dose calculations compared to monoenergetic alpha sources.
options: Average or maximum beta energy must be used for dose calculations since individual particles have variable energies
Dose calculations are identical for both
Beta's continuous spectrum makes dose calculations impossible
Only the minimum beta energy is used

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta's energy spectrum requires statistical approaches using average or endpoint energies, while alpha's fixed energy simplifies calculations.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta's variable energy requires average energy values for dose calculations, unlike alpha's monoenergetic emissions.

toLevel5.stem: Compare the radiation protection approaches needed for working with a 100 MBq beta source versus a 100 MBq gamma source. Evaluate the relative risks.
options: The beta source requires simple shielding (mm of aluminium) and prevention of contamination; the gamma source requires substantial shielding and distance
The beta source is more hazardous and requires more shielding
Neither source requires any protection at this activity level

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta is easily shielded (main concern is contamination control), while gamma requires heavy shielding and distance due to its penetrating ability.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta needs simple shielding plus contamination control; gamma needs substantial shielding, distance, and time management.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why bremsstrahlung (braking radiation) is a consideration when shielding high-energy beta emitters but not alpha emitters.
options: Beta particles' high speed and low mass cause them to decelerate rapidly in dense materials, emitting X-ray photons; massive alpha particles don't produce significant bremsstrahlung
Beta particles attract bremsstrahlung from surrounding materials
Bremsstrahlung only occurs with gamma radiation

feedback.correct: Correct! Accelerating charges emit radiation; lightweight, fast beta particles decelerate rapidly in dense materials, emitting bremsstrahlung. Heavy alphas decelerate gradually.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Bremsstrahlung results from rapid deceleration of charged particles. Light, fast betas produce it; heavy, slower alphas don't.
